summary: This is the trust agreement for 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two,' establishing a revocable trust with Jeffrey E. Epstein as Grantor and Jeffrey E. Epstein and Jeffrey A. Schantz as Trustees. It outlines extensive discretionary powers for the trustees, including managing assets for Epstein's benefit during his life and designating Darren Indyke as a successor trustee.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: He is the creator (Grantor) of the trust and also serves as one of its initial Trustees, with the trust established for his benefit during his lifetime.

persons.name: Jeffrey A. Schantz
persons.context: He is appointed as a co-Trustee of the trust and is granted the authority to designate or remove other trustees.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: He is named as the successor Trustee to replace Jeffrey A. Schantz if Schantz resigns or ceases to act without having designated another successor.

persons.name: Uren J. Kwintner
persons.context: A notary public in New York County who notarized the signatures of Jeffrey E. Epstein and Jeffrey A. Schantz on the trust agreement.

connections.description: Co-Trustees of the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two, jointly responsible for managing the trust assets.
Schantz is authorized to designate successor trustees, and Indyke is explicitly named as the successor if Schantz leaves without making a designation.

events.title: Execution of Epstein 2001 Trust Two
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein, as Grantor, and Jeffrey E. Epstein and Jeffrey A. Schantz, as Trustees, execute the trust agreement for 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two.'

keyFacts: Jeffrey E. Epstein established a revocable trust on November 8, 2001, initially funded with $100 in cash, granting himself and Jeffrey A. Schantz broad discretionary powers over the assets.
The trust agreement is governed by the laws of the United States Virgin Islands, suggesting an intent to utilize that jurisdiction's legal and tax framework.

Jeffrey A. Schantz holds significant authority, including the power to designate or remove other trustees, with Darren Indyke named as the automatic successor if Schantz leaves without making a designation.

The trust is for Epstein's benefit during his life, with provisions for distribution after his death, and includes a 'no-contest' clause to disinherit any beneficiary who challenges the trust or Epstein's will.
